# import libraries
import circlify
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Create just a figure and only one subplot
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(14,14))

# Title
ax.set_title('Suvery Repartition of the world')

# Remove axes
ax.axis('off')

# Find axis boundaries
lim = max(
    max(
        abs(circle.x) + circle.r,
        abs(circle.y) + circle.r,
    )
    for circle in circles
)
plt.xlim(-lim, lim)
plt.ylim(-lim, lim)

# Print circle the highest level (continents):
for circle in circles:
    if circle.level != 2:
      continue
    x, y, r = circle
    ax.add_patch( plt.Circle((x, y), r, alpha=0.5, linewidth=2, color="lightblue"))

# Print circle and labels for the highest level:
for circle in circles:
    if circle.level != 3:
      continue
    x, y, r = circle
    label = circle.ex["id"]
    ax.add_patch( plt.Circle((x, y), r, alpha=0.8, linewidth=2, color="#69b3a2"))
    plt.annotate(label, (x,y ), ha='center', color="white")

# Print labels for the continents
for circle in circles:
    if circle.level != 2:
      continue
    x, y, r = circle
    label = circle.ex["id"]
    plt.annotate(label, (x,y ) ,va='center', ha='center', bbox=dict(facecolor='white', edgecolor='black', boxstyle='round', pad=.5))

columns=data.columns
def plot_bar(start_index, end_index, title=None, rotation=45, figsize=(10,7)):
# start_index = 221
# end_index = 230
    data_dict = dict()
    for i in range(start_index,end_index):
        desc = ((data.iloc[0][i]).split('-')[-1]).strip()
        column = columns[i]
        desc = desc[:50]
        data_dict[desc] = data[column].count()

    sorted_dict=dict(sorted(data_dict.items(), key=lambda item: item[1], reverse=True))
    y=list(sorted_dict.values())[1:]
    l=np.sum(y)
    x=list(sorted_dict.keys())[1:]
    fig = plt.figure(figsize=figsize)
    ax=sns.barplot(x=x, y=y, palette='coolwarm')
    #plt.xlabel('Language Used')
    plt.title(title)
    plt.xticks(rotation=rotation)
    
    h_text = int(0.01*max(y))

    for p in ax.patches:
       ax.annotate('{}%'.format(np.round(p.get_height()*100/l,2)), (p.get_x()+0.1, p.get_height()+h_text))
    plt.tight_layout()

### Data science Tools and platform

Let’s now switchgear to find out what tools are technologies people are using. These diagrams are created specifically for India however, the same trends hold true for the rest of the world. 
 
First, let's have a look at what  programming languages are more popular. 
 
As you can see from the chart below , almost 34% of people use Python followed by SQL, C++ etc. What is interesting to see is that in the data science world C++ is more popular than Java or even R which was especially built for statisticians. Definitely Python is the clear winner here.
